{{otherships|HMAS Vendetta}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Ship country=Australia |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|Australia|naval}} |Ship builder=[[Williamstown Naval Dockyard]] |Ship laid down=4 July 1949 |Ship launched=3 May 1954 |Ship commissioned=26 November 1958 |Ship decommissioned=9 October 1979 |Ship motto=*''Vindico'' *I Avenge |Ship nickname= |Ship honours=*'''Battle honours:''' *[[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|Malaysia]] 1964–66 *[[Vietnam War|Vietnam]] 1969–70 *Seven [[HMAS Vendetta#Battle honours|inherited battle honours]] |Ship fate=Sold for scrap in 1987 |Ship notes= |Ship badge= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Ship class=[[Daring class destroyer (1949)|''Daring'' class destroyer]] |Ship displacement=*2,800 tons standard *3,600 tons full load |Ship length={{convert|390|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|43|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draught=*{{convert|12|ft|9|in|m|abbr=on}} mean *{{convert|14|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} deep |Ship propulsion=*2 × Foster Wheeler boilers *2 × English Electric geared turbines *2 shafts *{{convert|54,000|hp|abbr=on}} |Ship speed=Over {{convert|30|kn}} |Ship range={{convert|3700|nmi}} at {{convert|20|kn}} |Ship endurance= |Ship complement=20 officers, 300 sailors |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*6 × 4.5-inch guns (3 twin turrets) *6 × 40 mm Bofors (2 twin, 2 single) *5 × 21-inch torpedo tubes (pentad mount) *1 × Limbo mortar |Ship notes= }} |} '''HMAS ''Vendetta''''' was one of three [[Daring class destroyer (1949)|''Daring'' class]] destroyers built for and operated by the [[Royal Australian Navy]] (RAN). The destroyer was built by [[Williamstown Naval Dockyard]] and entered service in 1958. During her early career, ''Vendetta'' was deployed to the [[Far East Strategic Reserve]] on multiple occasions. In 1965 and 1966, the destroyer undertook deterrence patrols during the [[Indonesia-Malaysia Confrontation]]. Along with several runs escorting the troop transport {{HMAS|Sydney|R17|6}} to Vietnam, from late 1969 to early 1970 ''Vendetta'' was assigned to combat operations, and became the only Australian-built warship to serve in a shore bombardment role during the [[Vietnam War]].
The ship underwent a two-year modernisation from 1971 to 1973, and in December 1974 was one of thirteen RAN warships involved in [[Operation Navy Help Darwin]] after [[Cyclone Tracy]] devastated Darwin. Several more deployments were made to the Far East, up until 1978. In October 1979, the destroyer was decommissioned, and served as a [[parts hulk]] for sister ship {{HMAS|Vampire|D11|6}}. ''Vendetta'' was sold for [[ship breaking]] in January 1987.
==Design and construction== {{Main|Daring class destroyer (1949)}} The Royal Australian Navy initially ordered four [[Daring class destroyer (1949)|''Daring'' class destroyers]], which were to be named after the ships of the "[[Scrap Iron Flotilla]]" of World War II. The ships were modified during construction: most changes were made to improve habitability, including the installation of air-conditioning.<ref name=Coop167>Cooper, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 167</ref> ''Vendetta'' and her sister ships were the first all-welded ships to be constructed in Australia.<ref name=Coop168>Cooper, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 168</ref>
The ''Daring''s had a standard [[displacement (ship)|displacement]] of 2,800 tons, which increased to 3,600 tons at full load.<ref name=Bastock320>Bastock, ''Australia's Ships of War'', p. 320</ref> ''Vendetta'' and her sisters were {{convert|390|ft|m}} long, with a [[beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|43|ft|m}}, and a [[draught (hull)|draught]] of {{convert|12|ft|9|in|m}} at mean, and {{convert|14|ft|6|in|m}} at full or deep load.<ref name=Bastock320/> Her propulsion system consisted of two Foster Wheeler boilers, feeding two English Electric geared turbines, which provided {{convert|54000|hp}} to two propeller shafts.<ref name=Bastock320/> ''Vendetta'' could sail at over {{convert|30|kn|lk=in}}, and had a range of {{convert|3700|nmi|lk=in}} at {{convert|20|kn}}.<ref name=Bastock320/> Her standard ship's company consisted of 20 officers and 300 sailors.<ref name=Bastock320/>
''Vendetta''{{'}}s main armament consisted of six 4.5-inch guns mounted in three twin turrets, two forward and one aft.<ref name=Bastock320/> Her anti-aircraft outfit consisted of six [[40 mm Bofors]]; two single mountings on the forward superstructure, and two twin mountings on the aft superstructure.<ref name=Bastock320/> Five 21-inch torpedo tubes were fitted to a single pentad mount on the deck between the forward and aft superstructures.<ref name=Bastock320/> For anti-submarine warfare, a [[Limbo (weapon)|Limbo]] anti-submarine mortar was carried on the aft deck, offset to port.<ref name=Bastock320/>
''Vendetta'' was laid down at [[Williamstown Naval Dockyard]], Melbourne on 4 July 1949.<ref name=Bastock324>Bastock, ''Australia's Ships of War'', p. 324</ref> By 1950, it was already apparent that the Australian ''Daring''s would not be completed on time, as the Australian dockyards were experiencing difficulty in keeping up with the construction schedule.<ref name=Coop167/> The destroyer was launched on 3 May 1954 by the widow of [[Hector Waller]], who commanded the Scrap Iron Flotilla (including the original {{HMAS|Vendetta|D69|6}}) during World War II.<ref name=Bastock324/> On 18 July 1958, on the first occasion ''Vendetta'' engaged her engines during builder's trials, the destroyer accidentally rammed the [[Alfred Graving Dock|Alfred Dock]] caisson.<ref name=Bastock324/><ref name=Frame36>Frame, ''Where fate calls'', p. 36</ref> The collision was caused when the sailor manning the [[Engine order telegraph|engine telegraph]] incorrectly relayed an order of "half astern" as "half ahead", then repeated the mistake when the order was repeated to compensate for the first error.<ref name=Frame36/><ref name=Cassells160>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', p. 160</ref> ''Vendetta''{{'}}s bow breached the caisson, and threatened to flood the dock with {{HMAS|Quickmatch|G92|6}} inside.<ref name=Frame36/> A controlled flooding kept the caisson from failing and prevented damage to ''Quickmatch'' or further damage to ''Vendetta'', but the repairs to the destroyer's bow set completion back by three months.<ref name=Bastock324/><ref name=Frame36/>
''Vendetta'' was commissioned on 26 November 1958.<ref name=Bastock324/> By the time she was commissioned, the ship's cost increased from [[Australian pound|A£]]2.6 million to A£7 million.<ref name=Coop168/> Only three ships, {{HMAS|Voyager|D04|2}}, ''Vendetta'', and {{HMAS|Vampire|D11|2}}, were completed; the fourth was cancelled to save money.<ref>Cooper, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', pp. 168–9</ref> Like the preceding destroyer, ''Vendetta'' took her name from the concept of [[wikt:Vendetta|vendetta]], with the [[ship's badge]] depicting a [[stiletto]] dagger clenched in a fist, and the ship carrying the motto "''Vindico''", Latin for "I Avenge".<ref>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', pgs. 153, 163–4</ref>
==Operational history== ===1959–1969=== In April 1959, ''Vendetta'' operated in New Zealand waters, before visiting New Guinea in June.<ref>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', pp. 160–1</ref> After a refit, ''Vendetta'' and the frigate ''Quickmatch'' sailed to Singapore in October for a deployment to the [[Far East Strategic Reserve]] (FESR), which lasted until July 1960.<ref name=Bastock324/><ref name=Cassells161>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', p. 161</ref> ''Vendetta'' and the sloop {{HMAS|Swan|U74|2}} visited Tasmania in February 1961 for the [[Royal Hobart Regatta]].<ref name=Bastock324/> On 19 February, ''Vendetta'' rescued passengers from the [[Shaw Savill Line|Shaw Savill]] vessel ''Runic'', which had run aground on [[Middleton Reef]].<ref name=Cassells161/> The destroyer sailed for her second FESR deployment in April.<ref name=Bastock324/> During the six-month deployment, ''Vendetta'' operated on [[South East Asia Treaty Organisation]] exercises, visited ports in Borneo, Japan and Malaysia, and represented Australia at the [[Philippines]] independence celebrations.<ref name=Bastock324/> On her return, the destroyer underwent a refit at Williamstown.<ref name=Bastock324/>
[[File:Melbourne Darings 301014.jpg|thumb|left|An aircraft carrier sailing in close formation with two destroyers, one on each side.|''Vendetta'' sailing in close formation with sister ship ''Vampire'' and the aircraft carrier {{HMAS|Melbourne|R21|2}} in 1959]] ''Vendetta'' was deployed to the Far East in March 1962, and returned to Sydney in late June.<ref name=Bastock324/> The destroyer visited [[Noumea]] in August, then participated in Exercise Tuckerbox off North Queensland.<ref name=Bastock324/> In November, ''Vendetta'' visited Fremantle for the [[1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1962 Commonwealth Games]].<ref name=Bastock324/> After another refit, the destroyer's fourth FESR deployment commenced on 9 July 1963, when she left Sydney with {{HMAS|Quiberon|G81|2}}.<ref name=Cassells161/><ref name=Bastock325>Bastock, ''Australia's Ships of War'', p. 325</ref> While in the Far East, the two ships participated in SEATO Exercise Sea Dovetail, visited Japan, and assisted a disable United States-flagged freighter.<ref name=Bastock325/> ''Vendetta'' and ''Quiberon'' returned home via Guam Island and Manus Island on 20 February, after which ''Vendetta'' proceeded to Williamstown for refit.<ref name=Bastock325/>
''Vendetta'' returned to the FESR in mid-1964, this time escorting the aircraft carrier {{HMAS|Melbourne|R21|2}}, and remained in [[Southeast Asian]] waters until December.<ref name=Bastock325/> She remained in dock for the first half of 1965 undergoing refits, and on 11 August, sailed for her sixth Far East assignment, in company with {{HMAS|Duchess|D154|2}}.<ref name=Bastock325/> On 20 September, ''Vendetta'' and ''Duchess'' met the troop transport {{HMAS|Sydney|R17|2}} off [[Manus Island]]; ''Sydney'' was on her second troop transport voyage to Vietnam.<ref name=NottPayne170>Nott & Payne, ''The Vung Tau Ferry'', p. 170</ref><ref name=Grey106>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 106</ref> The two destroyers accompanied ''Sydney'' to [[Vung Tau]], where they arrived on 28 September, then escorted the troopship clear of the [[Market Time]] area before breaking off for Hong Kong.<ref name=NottPayne170/><ref name=Grey106/> In October, ''Vendetta'' operated as [[plane guard]] destroyer for {{HMS|Ark Royal|R09|6}}.<ref name=Bastock325/> During late 1965 and early 1966, the destroyer was assigned to deterrence patrols off [[Malaysian Borneo]] and the [[Singapore Straits]] as part of the Commonwealth involvement in the [[Indonesia-Malaysia Confrontation]].<ref name=Bastock325/>
''Vendetta'' and ''Duchess''' returned to Australia in March.<ref name=Bastock325/> On 20 May, the destroyer sailed to Jervis Bay following the sinking of the [[dredger]] ''W. D. Atlas'', and spent the next two days searching for survivors and bodies.<ref name=Bastock325/> ''Vendetta'' was again involved as a ''Sydney'' escort in May and June 1966, during the troopship's fourth voyage.<ref name=NottPayne171>Nott & Payne, ''The Vung Tau Ferry'', p. 171</ref> This run ended on 11 June, when ''Vendetta'' and ''Sydney'' reached Hong Kong.<ref name=NottPayne171/> On 3 November, the ship came to the aid of the [[United States Navy]] (USN) submarine {{USS|Tiru|SS-416|2}}, which had run aground on [[Frederick Reef]].<ref name=Bastock325/> After the submarine was refloated, ''Vendetta'' escorted her to Brisbane for repairs.<ref name=Bastock325/> On 5 March 1968, ''Vendetta'' and {{HMAS|Parramatta|DE 46|2}} sailed for six months in the Far East; ''Vendetta''{{'}}s seventh FESR deployment.<ref name=Bastock325/> The destroyer returned to Australia in October.<ref name=Bastock325/> The destroyer visited [[Newcastle, New South Wales]] for [[Australia Day]] (26 January) 1969, and operated in New Zealand waters during May.<ref name=Bastock325/>
===Vietnam deployment=== {{further|Military history of Australia during the Vietnam War}} In 1968, it was realised that the combination of maintenance requirements and other operational deployments meant that none of the RAN's three US-built [[Perth class destroyer|''Perth'' class]] destroyers would be available to serve in the [[Vietnam War]] once {{HMAS|Brisbane|D 41|6}} completed her deployment in late 1969.<ref name=FrameNPC235>Frame, ''No Pleasure Cruise'', p. 235</ref> They started investigating the possibility of deploying a ''Daring'' class destroyer, with the main concern being the supply of {{convert|4.5|in|mm|adj=on}} shells, as the USN destroyers were standardised to {{convert|5|in|mm|adj=on}} shells.<ref name=FrameNPC235/> After receiving reassurance from the USN that any logisitcal issues regarding Australian supplies, including ammunition, were "merely a problem to be overcome", ''Vendetta'' was marked for the deployment in November 1968, as she was the only available ''Daring'' or [[River class destroyer escort|River]] class vessel available.<ref name=FrameNPC235/><ref name=Grey207>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 207</ref> The decision to send ''Vendetta'' meant that the consistent deployment of an Australian warship with the [[United States Seventh Fleet]] since March 1967 would continue, and steps towards breaking a 'two-tier' culture within the RAN favouring the ''Perth'' class ships would be made, with associated benefits to morale.<ref name=Grey207/><ref name=Cooper204>Cooper, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 204</ref>
On 15 September 1969, ''Vendetta'' left Australia for South Vietnam, and relieved ''Brisbane'' at Subic on 26 September.<ref name=Bastock325/><ref name=Grey208>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 208</ref> While deployed to Vietnam, the destroyer was placed under the administrative control of [[Commander Australian Forces Vietnam]] in addition to that of the [[Flag Officer Commanding Australian Fleet]], while operationally, she was under the command of the Seventh Fleet.<ref>Grey, ''Up Top'', pp. 82–3</ref> A USN lieutenant was assigned to ''Vendetta'' to serve as a liaison.<ref name=Grey144>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 144</ref> Australia was the only allied nation to provide naval support to the United States Navy during the Vietnam War.<ref>Grey, ''Up Top'', pp. 94–5</ref> The destroyer's main activities were the provision of [[naval gunfire support]] to assist ground forces, particularly the United States Marine Corps units operating closest to the North Vietnam border.<ref>Grey, ''Up Top'', pp. 130–5</ref> Seven ships were usually stationed on the 'gunline', and attacks fell into two categories: 'unspotted' shelling of areas where North Vietnamese or Viet Cong forces and facilities were known or believed to be, and 'spotted' fire missions in direct support of ground troops.<ref>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 132</ref> In this role, ''Vendetta'' was assigned the callsign "Premier".<ref>Grey, ''Up Top'', pp. 155–6</ref>
''Vendetta'' sailed for a gunline assignment at [[Danang]] on 30 September.<ref name=Grey208/> While en route, the destroyer was replenished by a USN oiler, but there were problems because of the incompatibility between American fuel lines and British intakes, along with the standard pumping pressure being too high for ''Vendetta''{{'}}s system to handle; the first of numerous difficulties experienced by the British-designed ship operating with an American force.<ref name=Grey208/> Poor weather meant the ship did not arrive in Danang Harbour until 2 October, and she commenced naval gunfire support missions a day later.<ref name=Grey208/> After time at Danang, the ship sailed to the II Corps operating area, and continued gunline duties until 24 October.<ref name=Grey208/> She sailed to Singapore for maintenance, then resumed gunline duties on 9 November, assigned to the III Corps area.<ref name=Grey209>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 209</ref> ''Vendetta'' moved north to the I Coprs area two days later, then down to II Corps on 16 November.<ref>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 210</ref> At the end of November, the destroyer sailed to Taiwan for rebarrelling and other maintenance.<ref name=Grey211>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 211</ref> She returned to the gunline on 21 December, and on 1 January 1970, was called on to assist Market Time operations by firing on two small craft suspected to be on a supply run to Viet Cong positions.<ref name=Grey211/>
On 17 January, ''Vendetta'' was forced to sail to Hong Kong for boiler repairs.<ref name=Grey212>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 212</ref> Returning on 17 February, the destroyer was assigned to III Corps, and operated off Vung Tau in support of Australian and South Vietnamese units, along with a mercenary group.<ref name=Grey212/> Four days later, she was reassigned to II Corps.<ref name=Grey212/> On 6 March, the ship left the gunline to have two of her turrets rebarrelled at Subic, then returned to duty on 13 March.<ref>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 214</ref> The destroyer sailed to Subic on 23 March, and was relieved by {{HMAS|Hobart|D39|6}} on 30 March, after having fired 13,295 4.5-inch shells at 751 targets over five deployments.<ref name=Bastock326>Bastock, ''Australia's Ships of War'', p. 326</ref><ref name=Cassells162>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', p. 162</ref>
The destroyer was the only Australian-built warship to serve as a combatant in Vietnam,<ref name=Bastock326/> and the only ''Daring'' class destroyer to be operationally deployed in the shore bombardment role.<ref>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 321</ref> ''Vendetta''{{'}}s deployment to Vietnam under the new [[Australian White Ensign]], and patrols during the Indonesia-Malaysia Confrontation under the old ensign (identical to the British [[White Ensign]]), made the destroyer one of only two RAN vessels to deploy operationally under both ensigns.<ref>Fairfax, ''Navy in Vietnam'', p. 169</ref> Personnel awards for the deployment included one appointment as an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]], two [[Mentions in Despatches]], and 16 Naval Board commendations.<ref>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 126</ref>
===1970–1979=== ''Vendetta'' sailed for a FESR deployment in September 1970.<ref name=Bastock326/> She escorted the troopship ''Sydney'' for the third and final time during the former carrier's seventeenth voyage: ''Vendetta'' met the transport off Manila in late October, with the two ships in Vietnam during 31 October and 1 November.<ref name=Grey108>Grey, ''Up Top'', p. 108</ref><ref name=NottPayne175>Nott & Payne, ''The Vung Tau Ferry'', p. 175</ref> During November, the destroyer visited ports in India, before returning to Hong Kong for Christmas.<ref name=Bastock326/> She returned to Sydney in April 1971, and after participating in training exercises and a cruise in northern Australian waters, arrived in Williamstown on 29 September for her half-life modernisation refit.<ref name=Bastock326/> The modernisation cost US$20 million.<ref name=Jones218>Jones, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 218</ref> The fire-control system was replaced, a long-range air radar was installed, and the superstructure was modified, including a roof for the bridge.<ref name=Jones218/> ''Vendetta'' re-entered service on 2 May 1973.<ref name=Bastock326/>
From March until July 1974, ''Vendetta'' was again deployed to the Far East.<ref name="Cassells162"/> In October, the destroyer represented the RAN at celebrations of the centenary of [[Colonial Fiji|Fiji's cession to Britain]].<ref name=Cassells162/> Following the destruction of Darwin by [[Cyclone Tracy]] in December 1974, ''Vendetta'' was one of thirteen RAN ships deployed as part of the humanitarian aid mission [[Operation Navy Help Darwin]].<ref>Jones, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 234</ref> The destroyer sailed on 27 December from Sydney, and arrived on 3 January, with shore parties primarily assigned to the [[Nightcliff, Northern Territory|Nightcliff]] area.<ref name=Cassells162/> The destroyer remained in the area until late January.<ref name=Cassells162/> During mid-1975, ''Vendetta'' operated in the Far East.<ref name=Cassells162/> In August 1975, following tensions between Indonesia and the former Portuguese colony of East Timor (which cumulated in the Indonesian [[Indonesian invasion of East Timor|invasion]] in December), ''Vendetta'', ''Vampire'', and the supply ship {{HMAS|Supply||6}} were pre-positioned in Darwin in case they were needed for evacuations of Australian citizens or Timorese refugees.<ref name=Jones231>Jones, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 231</ref> Action by the ships was not required.
Most of 1976 was spent undergoing maintenance at Williamstown.<ref name=Cassells162/> In 1977, ''Vendetta'' was deployed to the Far East.<ref name=Cassells162/> Another deployment was made in 1978, starting in July.<ref name=Cassells162/> While en route, the destroyer visited Honiara to participate in celebrations of [[Solomon Islands]] independence from Australia.<ref name=Cassells162/>
==Decommissioning and fate== ''Vendetta'' paid off on 9 October 1979.<ref name=Cassells162/> After spending time moored near [[Bradleys Head]], during which she was used as a parts [[hulk (ship)|hulk]] for sister ship ''Vampire'', the destroyer was sold for [[ship breaking]].<ref name=Cassells162/> ''Vendetta'' was towed to her fate in January 1987.<ref name=Cassells162/>
Following an overhaul of the RAN [[battle honour]]s system, completed in March 2010, ''Vendetta''{{'}}s service was recognised with the honours "Malaysia 1964–66" and "Vietnam 1969–70".<ref name=newhonours>Royal Australian Navy, ''Navy Marks 109th Birthday With Historic Changes To Battle Honours''</ref><ref name=honourslist>Royal Australian Navy, ''Royal Australian Navy Ship/Unit Battle Honours''</ref>
